text:
McLuhan, Mrs. Elizabeth,
Vidora, Sask.,
1917.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 1
FORMER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to:
Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our province.

Name: MRS. ELIZABETH M. McLULAHAN
Address: Y. T. CORA

Birthplace: CLARKTON

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? ...1917...
Where did you set up housekeeping? ...600, 32-57-26-W-3...
Where had you been living before that? ...R.M. RICHARDSON, CLARKTON...
For how many people did you prepare meals? ...3...
How far was it to your nearest store? ...10 miles...
How often could a visit be made to the store? ...twice a week...
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? ...groceries, flour, oatmeal, salt, sugar, tea, coffee...

Tell: Alice Fisk, Cora Scott

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ...Ogilvie...

In what quantities did you buy it? ...100 lbs...

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? ...$1.75 - $2.25...

How much did you use graham flour? ...2 lbs. per year...

Was flour milled locally? ...Yes... How far away? ...H.O... What year? ...1913...

What was the price for a thirty pound bag of rolled oats? ...80 cents...

What other grain products did you use? ...corn meal, whole wheat, oatmeal...

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? ...Yes...

How did you grind it? ...using a mill...
McLahan, Mrs. Elizabeth,
Vidora, Sask.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES PRESENTMENTS
No. 1

PIONEER DEPT. WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS SAY?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to:
Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our province.)

Name: MRS. ELIZABETH M. McLAHAN
Address: VIDORA
Birthplace: ONTARIO

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start homesteading in western Canada? 1917

Where did you set up homesteading? 32-5 - W-3

Where had you been living before that? 4/4 mile north of present location

For how many years have you lived here? 3

How far was it to your nearest store? 10 miles

How often could a visit be made to the store? 4 times a month

What cereals did you usually buy in those earliest years? Sugar, flour, oatmeal, salt, butter, tea, dried fruit, cooking supplies

2. FLours AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Ogilvie's

In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.75 - $2.25

How much did you use graham flour? 25 lbs

Was flour milled locally? Yes

How far away? 40 miles

What was the price for a thirty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.00

What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal

Other? No

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No

How did you grind it? With a stone mill
2.

3. SUGAR AND STARCH

In what quantity did you buy milk? 10 lbs. 40¢
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 80¢
What brand or folder or type did you use? Poveshull
What size of tin or can did you usually buy? 4 lb. 50¢
At what price? 45¢ or 50¢

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

Did you take a supply of fresh milk in the early days?
That was the price of butter? 20¢
Did you prefer eggs for breakfast? Yes
Did you take butter? Yes
What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

Did you ever eat at Argent's? Yes
How did you get fresh meat? Butcher shop at the Hardware store
How often did you get fresh meat? Weekly
For did you purchase meat? Hardware store
Was there a "meat ring" in your neighborhood? Yes
If so, what year was it organized? About 1923
Did you use games? No
About kinds?

For how long? Until the war ended
What part did fish play in the family diet? Fish was eaten
Was the fish fresh, canned, or frozen? Fresh
Kinda? Mullet
McLuhan, Mrs. Elizabeth,
Villars, Sante.
1917.

1. SUGAR AND SPICES

In what quantity did you buy milk sugar? 50¢
That was the price? For a ten pound bag of milk sugar? 60¢
Have you tried different brands or types? Yes
What size of milk container did you use? 1/2 gal.
At what price? 45¢ per quart

2. DAIRY PRODUCTS

Has milk been found in your neighborhood? Yes
What kind of milk? Whole milk
Did you take butter? Yes
What kind of butter?
How much do you pay for butter? 20¢
Did you purchase cream? Yes
Did you purchase eggs? Yes
Did you purchase cheese? No

3. MEAT AND FISH

How often do you eat meat? Daily
How much do you spend on meat? 50¢
How many times do you buy meat? Weekly
How much meat do you buy? 2 lbs
How often do you purchase fish? Weekly
How much do you spend on fish? 50¢
How much fish do you buy? 2 lbs
Do you purchase poultry? Yes
How much do you spend on poultry? 50¢
How much poultry do you buy? 2 lbs

4. VEGETABLES

What vegetables do you usually purchase? Potatoes, carrots, celery
How much do you spend on vegetables? 50¢
How much vegetables do you buy? 2 lbs
Do you purchase fruits? Yes
How much do you spend on fruits? 50¢
How much fruit do you buy? 2 lbs

5. OTHER ITEMS

What other items do you purchase? Bread, milk, eggs, cheese, butter
How much do you spend on these items? 50¢
How much of these items do you buy? 2 lbs
Do you purchase coffee? Yes
How much do you spend on coffee? 50¢
How much coffee do you buy? 2 lbs
Do you purchase tea? Yes
How much do you spend on tea? 50¢
How much tea do you buy? 2 lbs
Do you purchase chocolate? Yes
How much do you spend on chocolate? 50¢
How much chocolate do you buy? 2 lbs
Do you purchase candy? Yes
How much do you spend on candy? 50¢
How much candy do you buy? 2 lbs

For how long?

That part did Miss [name] play in this family show? 1 week
Which church or chapel? Church of the Good Shepherd
Kind of? Protestant
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? 
At what price? 
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) 
Price? 
What other beverages did you buy?

7. VEGETABLES AND FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel here? 
To put up housekeeping? 
If not, where from? 
That year did you start growing your own supply for the winter of? 
Potatoes 
Cabbage 
Carrots 
Turnips 
Beets 
In what quantities did you buy while navy beans? 
How did you buy prunes? (in bulk or by the box)? 
What weight? 
How did you buy apples? 
That other dried fruits did you use in the summer days? (apricots, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by canning? 
Peas? 
Beans? 
Other foods? 
That year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 
That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 
That year did you first preserve nuts by canning? 
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? 
To what extent? 
Did you make your own vinegar? 
For how many years?
5. **BEVERAGES**

   What kind of tea did you buy? [Blank]
   At what price? [Blank]
   What kind of coffee did you buy? [Blank] (beans or ground)
   At what price? [Blank]

6. **VEGETABLES AND FRUITS**

   What was the weight of potatoes per bushel then you had up housekeeping? [Blank]
   If not, where from? [Blank]
   That year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of potatoes? [Blank]
   Turnips? [Blank]
   In what quantities did you buy? [Blank]
   How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? [Blank]
   What weight? [Blank]
   How did you store prunes? [Blank]
   What other dried fruits did you use in the summer days? (apricots, pears, apples, peaches, loquats, raisins, currants, or others)? [Blank]

7. **PRESERVING**

   In the early years did you preserve any foods by canning? [Blank]
   Beans? [Blank]
   Suet, tomatoes? [Blank]
   That year did you first preserve fruit by canning? [Blank]
   That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? [Blank]
   That year did you first preserve meat by canning? [Blank]
   To what extent? [Blank]
   Did you make your own vinegar? [Blank]

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal Yeast Cake
Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes
Using hops? No
Did you buy baking powder? Yes
Baking soda? Yes
Cream of tartar? No
Did you make your own baking powder? No
| FOOD                  | Year YOU first ran when buying it in the store | How much it bought, 10 lb. box, 10 lb. can, etc., usually at each supply store, or this amount | Ant. you bought, 10 lb. box, 10 lb. can, etc., usually at each supply store, or this amount | Price of each |
|----------------------|-----------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------|
| Soda biscuits        | 1911                                          | 40¢                                                                                              | 35¢                                                                                      | 40¢          |

| store cheese)        |                                               |                                                                                                  |                                                                                          |              |
| Vanilla              |                                               |                                                                                                  |                                                                                          |              |

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal Yeast Cake
Did you make yeast for your own use? No
Using starter? No
Salt rising? No
Did you buy baking powder? Yes
Baking soda? Yes
Cream of tartar? No
Did you make your own baking powder? No

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ... 

How far was this water from your home? (rail, barrel, tank) ...

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

...

| FOOD | Earliest date it appeared on the market | Approximate price at the time | How did it differ from the same product today? |

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ... well ...

How far was this water from your home? (pail, barrel, tank) ... 1/4 mile ...

How was it brought to the home? (pail started housekeeping), giving places where possible.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping. Giving places where possible.

(Handwritten note: "Water came from the fields from dry out of our kitchens, house through the pump system with three lifts for dry out of..."
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If you made your own, did you use lye? What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle?

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Where did you get your fuel?

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made? What year was it purchased? What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see enamel ware? Aluminum?
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Bought from store.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes.

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Soap with lye.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood.

Where did you get your fuel? From nearby woods.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Burned wood and coal.

Began to use gas around 1910.

Professionally cooked by electric range.

Professionally cooked by gas.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) No.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? Unknown.

What year was it purchased? 1900.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

For preparing food (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see enamel ware? 1910.

Aluminum? 1910.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS
Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received
with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Most foods were purchased in bulk
and packed in paper or cardboard boxes.

To last year: 1926-1925: The chocolate
felt containers wrapping came first.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest
year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family
with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or
summer.

Breakfast - Oatmeal, Creamed Wheat, Biscuits, Eggs, Coffee
Dinner - Meat, Potatoes, Vegetables, Gravy
Supper - Bread, Butter, Fruit, Milk

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada?
Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

1917 - Grandfather, Grandmother, Father, Mother, Son, Daughter
Father by Mother's side, Son by Mother's side
Father by Mother's side, Son by Mother's side

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level, living on one or two locally
procured foods? Give details.

Not quite starvation levels. Mostly always
had potatoes, peas, turnips, carrots, stored in
cellar under house. No varied variety in food.

poorly guaranteed, of dried fruits.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS
Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received
with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest
year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family,
with their ages at the time.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada?
Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level, living on one or two locally
produced foods? Give details.

Plot quite starvation level. Mostly always
had potatoes, peas, turnip, carrots, etc., in
clear under house. No fresh variety in food.
poorly guaranteed of dried fruits.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods. In other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of purchasing, prices, preservation etc. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

When it was necessary to purchase groceries and foods in town, fifty cents away from the supplies required. On one occasion something was forgotten, the second time to their credit trip to town which worked probably be four or five months especially if it were urgent time. Putting with them and working for that distance was all along a pleasure trip.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home-made and home-prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods. In other ways during pioneer days in western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, etc. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Remember, every thing requires something else, for there's no harm in having to wait until they're free for two weeks, probably be four or five months especially if it been winter time. Putting them away will always a for their distance, we'll always a pleasure trip.
Oxford
No. 613 S
